title: Did Ringo Starr really add to the Beatles success in a way that Pete Best couldn’t have? Everything I have heard about Ringo implies he was a solid, if not spectacular, drummer. - Quora

response.answer_text: Watch A Hard Day’s Night. Yes, Ringo added to the Beatles success. He wasn’t a “great” drummer according to the snobs, but I’m not so sure that if he was an amazing drummer it would have added much to the Beatles. When it comes to instrumentation, what made the Beatles stand out was how they worked together. If they wanted a sound, they would figure out how to get it. A rock and roll band is not a symphony orchestra. Not everyone has to be “tight”. And shocking as it may be, popularity is paramount in a rock group. Popularity among the fans certainly, but also being popular among your band mates. And Ringo was both. This is why I suggest you watch A Hard Day’s Night. Does Ringo bash? Does Ringo swing? Does Ringo roll? Maybe not, but he does the one thing that makes a successful drummer. Ringo CLICKS. He clicks with the audience, he click with his mates. They just get along so fabulously in person, on stage, and on record. He’s RINGO! Remember that the Beatles are entertainers. Image, performance, personality, all these things went with the package for a group that was successful on the radio, in television, and in movies. Ringo is an enormous part of Beatlemania and the cult of the Beatles. It’s a testament to his ability as a drummer that he wasn’t just a funny face or stage-presence and that he always contributed to the records on every track. Except for a couple of early recordings and maybe two White Album cuts which were recorded while he was on vacation and Macca drummed on personally (competently at best), they never once had to replace him or record over his drumming with some hardened, professional conservatory-trained session player. He always delivered exactly what the others asked for. Every Beatles record has one track where he sings vocals for a reason. It was like an artist’s final signature on a painting. This is a Fab FOUR record. We hereby sign (sing) together. I won’t get into the politics of what being in the Beatles was like according to various sources, including the guys themselves. But I will say this, I’m like 99% certain that a Beatles without Ringo Starr would probably have lasted about two records tops. There would have been no Beatlemania. There would have been no A Hard Day’s Night (literally. the title is attributed to a Ringo saying) or Help! Certainly no Rubber Soul/Revolver and beyond. They probably would have started arguing during Love Me Do and broken up acrimoniously after charting with a couple of covers of 1950’s staples and maybe some song foisted on them by their producer. They would have been like Gerry and The Pacemakers. They wouldn’t be The Beatles. People forget that it isn’t just the quality of the songwriting or the playing. WHO is just as important as what, which is why I always say that if you went back in time to 1961 and started trying to hawk all the Beatles songs as your own, you’d be lucky if you were able to sell a couple in tin-pan alley and have them become minor hits for soon to be forgotten artists.

“Did Ringo Starr really add to the Beatles success in a way that Pete Best couldn’t have? Everything I have heard about Ringo implies he was a solid, if not spectacular, drummer.” This is what comes of reading idle nonsense written by naysayers, instead of directly learning about something yourself. The only way to really understand enough to answer such a question logically, is to learn enough about music and how it is crafted, so as to be able to tell the difference between a performer who is “solid, but not spectacular,” and one who is a core creative artist, contributing unique and essential elements to the final product. Go and STUDY DRUMMING. Not as in trying to become a drummer yourself, that’s unnecessarily expensive. Just gather up a large quantity of songs that you enjoy or don’t care for all that much, by leading artists and by those who just had a song or so become hits. Then listen carefully to each drummers participation. You will find that some drummers just keep the beat, and add occasional “fills” as required, while others actually play an entire evolving and unique pattern of drumming, clearly designed to support the changes in the music that take place during the song. Ringo was for the Beatles, the latter kind of drummer. If you pay attention to the details, you will learn that on some of their most popular and powerful hits, that it was Ringo's drumming that lifted the song out of mundane lethargy, and made it into a genuine work of true art. The only people who assert that Ringo in the Beatles was a “solid but not spectacular drummer,” are the kind of limited-appreciation folks who think that what makes a drummer great, is the ability to play twice as many drums during a song as anyone else, and play twice as many beats and cymbal crashes as anyone else, whether the song warrants it or not. The truly GREAT creative musicians of any kind, are the ones who play exactly what the music most requires, including playing nothing at all, when that is what is needed.

To answer the question we must go to the some of the conclusions we can draw from the expert Beatles biographer Mark Lewisohn and his Tuned In biography of the pre 1964 yrs. Mark uncovered and clarified some commonly held beliefs, like Pete Best, a novice drummer with little experience was the ONLY drummer they could get to go to Germany. Ringo was in another group at the time. They barely knew of him if at all at the time. So they took Pete to Germany and he became a Beatle. For 2 yrs he played and improved, but he didn’t mix well with the other 3 personalities, often going off on his off duty time while Paul George and John grew closer. Pete developed some as a drummer but the other 3 were always improving their music and became a tight band that astounded everyone when they returned home. Pete’s drumming was good for informal crowds and gigs. The Beatles got several minor recording work and each time Pete was limited by the producers to basic support. The Decca tryout shows him playing basic drums but nothing impressive, and some say his timing was off. All 4 were nervous and didn’t get the contract. Then EMI and George Martin came along. Martin didn’t want to use Best on the drums for recording. He also said he didn’t tell them to drop Best as he could play live adequately. But the 3 Beatles were always seeking out better sound and they were consistently being told Best was not the Best. By the time they met Martin they had known Ringo for years, getting along well together, and they played with Ringo as a fill in drummer a few times. The difference to the 3 musicians was astounding. The EMI recording was the last chance for Best and they decided to take Martin’s refusal to use Best as just cause. The 3 decided to let him go, ordering (quite cowardly as they later made known) their manager to inform Best. Ringo was about to be available, so they asked him to join. Ironically, Ringo was also not approved by Martin as his 1st performance in the studio was off because Ringo was nervous, as the other 3 had been at Decca. But Ringo got another shot and impressed Martin enough to let him remain the drummer in the studio on all future songs. Ringo’s near perfect timing and matching personality made him a great choice for drummer, and he was just what they needed — not demanding or flashy, perfect take after take, to take them the rest of the way to the top!

Did Ringo Starr really add to the Beatles success in a way that Pete Best couldn’t have? Everything I have heard about Ringo implies he was a solid, if not spectacular, drummer. A~~~~~~~~~ People forget that Ringo brought more to the table than perceived drumming talent. I hate to spread rumors, but the stories I’ve heard about Pete was that he was a bit of a loner. After gigs, he didn’t hang out with the band—is one rumor, I heard. As far as personality—he didn’t really fit in with the others—another rumor. Ringo is bright and smart and funny. Ever notice how funny the others are? This is the direct result of being smart. Ringo fit in—he could joke around on equal terms—with all the others. This alone—barring his drumming—already makes him a better fit than Pete—that is—IF—the rumors about Pete were true. I have no idea if they are. So even if Ringo had the same drumming skill as Pete—his personality alone made him a better fit for the Beatles. His agreeable personality would allow the band to remain together longer. With Pete, the band may have lasted only 3 years. This isn’t a slam on Pete—the point is—we have no way to know. Any change in line-up has long-term effects. Drumming is just one aspect. Personality is another.

It’s wholly impossible to answer that question if you include Pete Best in the equation. That’s because there’s absolutely no way to know what Pete Best could have or would have done had he been a Beatle. For all we know he might have had an extraordinary latent talent that would have only blossomed in the creative environment that the Beatles provided. George Harrison started out in the early 60’s as solid but average lead guitarist and mediocre songwriter. Yet by the end of the 60’s he had become an extraordinary songwriter, and had introduced and fused Eastern music and even Eastern scales with Western pop. Both were remarkable achievements and examples of human potential becoming fully realized, or more realized, in the right environment. And in the 70’s he developed a guitar style that’s instantly recognizable. There’s a big difference between talent or ability and latent talent or ability. That boring bald accountant in your office or the office down the street might have been an Einstein or Shakespeare or Descartes or Winston Churchill had he been in a different environment. All we can do is measure Ringo as Ringo and what he’s done, which is provide the solid grounding, perfect balance and center-point of gravity that was needed for the groundbreaking innovation of the Beatles as a whole.

Being a solid drummer was the best possible thing he could have been. He was the solidest drummer of his generation. Were any of the other Beatles spectacular players? No. Let’s not kid ourselves about that. They were all capable and inventive but they all understood that their role was to serve the song, not show off. The recorded evidence shows that Pete Best was both stiff and unreliable: in the version of ‘Love Me Do’ that he plays on, his lurch into twist-beat for the middle eight sounds arbitrary because it’s just not that kind of song. Ringo, by contrast, maintains the same discreet backbeat throughout because he knew that there was no need to do anything else. Forget what you’ve heard about Ringo and really listen to what he plays. He practically never plays the same part twice. Each song has its own drum part unique to it. That is the kind of drummer the Beatles needed: meticulous and precise. Not a show-off. If you’ve never before noticed just how varied and responsive Ringo’s drumming really is, I envy you. You’re in for a treat.

IMO the success of The Beatles did not just relate to their songs, but to their personalities also. They complemented each other as musicians and very much as singers. But their personalities seemed to blend nicely. Paul was the polite pretty one, John was in your face and witty, George was reserved and mysterious, and Ringo was effervescent and funny. The Beatles’ package was a mixture of musical excellence and personalities that gave the ‘band’ an appealing persona. From the accounts I have read, George, John and Paul were not all that thrilled with Pete and it is alleged they resented his appeal with the girls because of his good looks. That in itself is evidence of friction within the band and may have impacted negatively on them. From all reports Pete was a reasonable drummer. With respect to Ringo’s drumming skills, I think he has been given an unfair go by so called critics over the years. He has been judged as fair - good by some, while others have applauded his drumming. During the era of The Beatles I recall comments that he was unconventional and unique in his style. Personally, I loved his drumming, especially on “Strawberry Fields Forever” and “All You Need Is Love”. As I have mentioned elsewhere, Ringo’s drumming helped some of The Beatles’ memorable songs become classics IMO. I have concluded that the negative critics over the years were probably envious and jealous of Ringo and really were not good enough themselves to judge him. Our memories of Ringo will linger for decades whereas they are but a speck of dust lost in a wind that fizzled out long ago!

Then what you have heard about Ringo is wrong. Being self-taught and untrained, he had his own unique style - he didn't even hold the sticks properly, clenching them in his fists rather than holding them like a pencil like a trained drummer would. He didn't lock the kick drum in with the bass guitar, as a conventional drummer would. And being a left-handed drummer playing a right-handed kit, he played unconventionally, putting emphasis in places where others wouldn't because he led with his left hand, not his right. He wasn't a flashy drummer - he wasn't interested in drum solos or showing off, but he understood his job as a timekeeper, and did it well. He could keep time like a metronome. His playing was different, and gave the Beatles a unique sound that helped them stand apart from the crowd in a way that people couldn't quite put their finger on. And the band's popularity and influence was such that he pretty much pioneered rock drumming. Ringo's unconventional style became the norm.

Ringo definitely added to the Beatles success and they wouldn’t have been nearly as good without him. He wasn’t flashy or a thundering beast behind the kit. He was a long way off Keith Moon, Ginger Baker or John Bonham when it comes to dazzling stick work. But he was a metronome behind the kit. He played a perfect beat over and over again. While John and Paul, and later George, were experimenting and trying to work out how to play a song in the studio, they could rely on Ringo to give them what they wanted on the drums every time. George Martin commented once that he couldn’t think of a single take that broke down because of Ringo. The others fluffed their parts but Ringo was bang on every time. He was the perfect drummer for the band. Pete Best on the other hand, just wasn’t a very good drummer. He just lacked the skills that even a competent drummer requires. During the days in Hamburg, the Beatles had a habit of pounding the stage with their feet. John, Paul and George would stomp on the stage in unison which people assumed was their attempt to generate further excitement but the truth is that they were trying to get Pete back in time because he’d wandered off the beat. Best was barely adequate for sloppy rock and roll played to drunken sailors in Hamburg’s red light district. He was totally incapable in the studio.

I grew up listening to (and falling in love with) the Beatles’ music played on an inexpensive, single-speaker record player. Something like this:  Given the limitations of the equipment, one could barely hear the rhythm section—it was vocals and guitars to the fore, with the beat just thumping along in the background. In around 1969, a few other boys and I were assigned to clean up our school’s auditorium the morning after a concert. The priest supervising our work told us we were free to listen to music, and powered up the sound system for our use. He may even have generously left a couple of Dermot O’Brien or Larry Cunningham LPs for our entertainment. As soon as the priest had left, however, one of the other boys (who’d had this gig before), put his copy of Sgt. Pepper’s on the turntable and cranked up the volume.  Now, I had practically worn out my copy of Pepper’s on the player at home, and thought that I knew every nuance on the album. Oh, the revelation of listening to Sgt. Pepper’s on good sound equipment! I remember in particular my amazement at hearing the bass and drums clearly for the first time. Paul was playing these inventive counter melodies, instead of just contributing a rhythm 1–2–3 like a string bass player would. But the drums! Every part that Ringo played was different, unique to that song, and his drumming was quite melodic in places (e.g., “A Day in the Life”). It was not until the George Martin remasters were released by EMI in 2009 that most people could hear the Beatles in their full glory on our players at home. And once again, the rhythm section was a revelation. By that point, of course, few disputed that Paul McCartney was a really good—maybe great—bass guitarist. But I challenge anyone to listen to the 2009 remasters and then claim that Ringo Starr is anything less than a stellar drummer.

Short answer: You heard right! Longer answer: Pete Best, by all accounts, just WASN'T a very good drummer! He wasn't solid, nor was he particularly consistent, 2 things that a good drummer HAS to have! As a musician myself, let me give you an idea of what happened there. I've played with more than one drummer who had NO 'foot'; I couldn't get a 'beat' from them, and that made it REALLY hard to play well! One in particular played a lot of flashy fills, but was all around the beat; of course, he thought he was God's Gift to Drummers, so you couldn't tell HIM anything… Pete Best was that kind of drummer! A friend of mine - who, sadly, died of cancer several years ago - was the kind of guy that you could set behind a drumset, give him a beer, and he'd be as happy as a clam, and play all night long! He was solid - not flashy - and could play pretty much ANYTHING! Ringo was THAT kind of drummer! Which one would YOU rather play with? The Beatles had that same choice; of course, they DEFINITELY made the RIGHT choice!

Pete as the other Beatles have mentioned in the past got the job because he had a set of drums. He wasn’t that good. George Martin didn’t ask that Pete be fired. He just told them that he was going to use a session drummer. So the Beatles or should say Brian took it upon themselves to get rid of Pete. They liked Ringo and had played with him on numerous occasions. He was the perfect fit. George Martin was impressed. In those days they didn’t have click tracks or drum machines. Martin said Ringo was their click track. That’s how spot on he was. Listen to “Back In The USSR”. A song on the White Album that was recorded after Ringo quite. It’s kind o messy. Reason? All three of the other Bealtes contributed to the drums. It was a composite of all three. The song also isn’t in perfect time. Kind of wonders. Yeah I would say Ringo was rock solid. If I had the money I would have Ringo and Jim Keltner playing on every song I ever recorded.

I’ve always loved the Beatles…from when I was 10 years old in 1964 to this day. But it wasn’t until the last 10 or so years that I REALLY listened closely and in great detail, dissecting every musical nuance…..especially Paul’s bass and Ringo’s drums. Keeping with the question…. First, it is well agreed that Pete Best was adequate at best (no pun intended). Second, after deep listening, it is my personal opinion that Ringo was a drum genius. Yes, he was never flashy. But what he added to each song was exactly what the song needed. His fills and occasional flairs were always spot on to the song. I marvel at his contributions to some of the greatest recordings ever created. I think back to late 1963 and the first times I heard “I Want to Hold Your Hand”. To me, the little triplet drum flairs between the verse and chorus was as delightful as any other part of the song and still gives me goosebumps. Ringo was no less important to the whole of the Beatles than any other of the group and I truly doubt any other drummer would have compared at the time.

Yes, Ringo was compatible with the other Beatles personality wise. His nature was upbeat, like his drumming. He added a lift and a certain creative quality to their sound . Pete Best, on the other hand, was a plodding drummer with a heavy foot. He was often off time, which was apparent in the ballads ; in Love Me Do, you can hear how he tears the song down with his attempts at an alternate rhythm . He had no feel. In the Hamburg clubs, he was probably effective on the fast rock n roll songs. They were rowdy places, and Pete could kick it into gear . He wasn’t horrible. Otherwise they would have gotten rid of him sooner .The proof is that the Beatles were gaining positive attention there .He was actually popular back in Liverpool too, but from all acounts it was for his looks. In all respects, Pete Best was very acceptable as a live drummer in a provincial setting, but not on the international road map . Ringo was perfect for the Beatles. He made them ready for the world .

Ringo Starr was not a “drummer’s drummer”. But he was such an improvement over Pete Best who was a lousy one! Ringo ‘fit in’ with the lads, and was a rock solid player and performer. His playing in 1963 thru 1965 was good, if not spectacular for simple Rock n Roll music. He put the ‘beat’ in The Beatles, and was the final link in the chain!  I saw an old talk show interview with Pete Best on TV recently. He ‘claimed’ that he was totally blindsided by the group when their manager fired him. He also said that he held no grudges and wished them well. What complete bullshit! Pete was the dark, handsome one in the early Beatles who never really fit in with the band. His ‘teddy boy’ looks didn’t match once Brian Epstein entered into the picture. His playing was criticized by Producer George Martin, who insisted on using a session drummer in the studio. The writing was on the wall.

I wasn't going to answer but then decided to anyway. Firstly an emphatic yes! Ringo added the missing piece to the puzzle that was the Beatles. John, Paul and George knew it the first time Ringo ever sat in for Pete on a set he missed. What's more Ringo fit them personally quickly becoming a close friend of theirs, Pete had no inclination to be their friend. The Beatles were a tight knit band of extremely close friends save for Pete, it was one of the unique attributes of the band. I managed to find a versus video, there are a few if you go to YouTube

I prefer to stick to solid facts. The Beatles auditioned for Parlophone and succeeded. Parlophone agreed to release a single, Love Me Do, but it substituted a session musician instead of Best for the release. They were very young and handled it badly. I wish history had shown that at least one of the other three had the gumption to go and break it to Pete that they couldn’t - seriously couldn’t - risk continuing with a drummer whose contribution their recording company had taken off the record. I wish they’d spoken to him afterwards rather than ignoring him until the Anthology recordings were released and I’m glad he at least got his due for those. They behaved like asses. But did Ringo add something that Pete Best couldn’t? Yes. The recording company let him on the records in a way they didn’t with Pete. That’s the objective fact.

Forget about the drumming. The Beatles’ success was built more on their personality than their music. Don’t get me wrong; their music was great and something new. But what really pushed them over the top was their personalities, especially as shown in the two movies they made early on “A Hard Day’s Might” and then “Help.” Ringo had the right personality to fit with the rest of the group and was a wonderful comic actor. I don’t think that Pete Best could have brought any of that to the Beatles. Think of the Marx Brothers. You had Groucho, Chico, and Harpo. But there were other brothers as well and in the earliest movies there was a fourth brother joining in, Zeppo or maybe it was Gummo. But the fourth brother had no real flare for comedy and became something of an afterthought or straight man. That is what Pete Best would have been; and it would have hindered the development of the other three as personalities. Also, don’t forget some of Ringo’s malapropisms that led to some of their best songs, such as “A Hard Day’s Night,” “Eight Days a Week,” and “Tomorrow Never Knows.” Ringo brought a lot more to the Beatles than just a back beat.

What do your ears tell you? My ears tell me that, from the earliest recordings the Beatles made with him that he was a solid drummer who came up with a lot of very unique parts, who could play the myriad rhythms of r&b, country, rockabilly, pop, “UK beat” music and more. And yet all those songs have his unique stamp on them. My ears tell me that he was the BEST musician in the group, at least in 1963 (when they recorded the most songs: all those BBC songs!) doing exactly what was right for each song, yet expressing his ample personality abundantly through his drumming. You can read a million opinions. In the end its your ears who should make your decisions. Not some writer who uses mathematics to prove that one drummer is better than another. There is no wrong way to do art, especially rock music. It’s not engineering. Ringo did it his way and you like it or you don’t.

The most common answer that I’ve seen from actual musicians and real experts (I’m not included in either category) is that Ringo was masterful at anchoring and complimenting the other three. I think because he doesn’t have a huge library of flashy solos he doesn’t get the attention he deserves. My favorite bit of his drumming is on “Nowhere Man.” His work is subtle and very musical. Personality wise he was by all accounts a better fit than Pete Best. He was not only the musical, but also the emotional anchor for the group. In an answer to a similar question a Quoran noted that Ringo had a special knack for picking up on the quirks and suggestions of the other three. George Martin was never really sold on Pete’s ability and that probably would have meant a parade of studio musicians. The impact of that situation would be very hard to judge, although you can certainly make the argument that part of the group’s greatness came from the creative juices that flowed when they were in the pressure-cooker studio environment.

Ringo added to the Beatles success because he was a “Personality” ! He was so cute in Hard Days Night & Help. He sang and got along with all the other members, if you were ever in a band, getting along in the recording studio and the tours is VERY important! John Lennon felt he was so important he had Ringo get a share of the songwriting royalties (which is BIG) even tho Ringo didn’t write ‘em! Also, as a drummer I wouldn’t have played the beats any different; they were perfect for the SONGS! Many jazz drummers could have added more flair, But why?

Pete Best was a barely adequate drummer, and he really did not ‘mesh’ or ‘gel’ with the other Beatles socially or in any other way. He had to go. They chose Ringo because they had already known him for quite a while, they liked him and they knew he was a good drummer. They knew that very well from seeing him play in Hamburg, including the times when he filled in for Pete. They did not need a spectacular drummer. Usually solid is what you need. Nobody plays ‘lead drums’. All this recent talk about ‘Ringo was not really very good’ is pointless, silly, and not based on facts.

If you were a middle-schooler when you first brought home The Beatles Second Album, you noticed immediately that this music JUMPS out of the speakers. Adults tended to dismiss it as ‘too damn loud,’ but that’s not quite accurate. You could play it at a low volume and get the same impression. This was due in large part to Ringo’s arrangements, his sense of appropriateness, the accurate time he kept, and the absolute perfect tempo he chose and maintained. He had a tendency to use triplets in his fills that somehow suggests ‘show-biz.’ This has a comic effect to me, but instead of satirizing, it just makes it good fun.

Everybody other Beatle said that he did. Ringo was a far better technical drummer than Pete, could play in a greater variety of styles, could keep time more consistently than Pete, and got along with them on a personal level, while Pete didn’t share their sense of humor and tended to be moody and a bit of a loner-which they probably could have tolerated had he not had limits on his ability as a drummer which had led George Martin to decide that Pete would not be allowed to play on any of the albums.

The reader who asked this question for sure doesn’t know much about The Beatles. But I can understand that. Anyway, any person who knows the Beatles meaning would never doubt about that for a single moment. Ringo IS a Beatle. Pete was not. Therefore he always was the element that was missing for them to suceed. Without him Beatlemania would have never happened.

Check Google/Youtube for a video called “what makes Ringo a great drummer” from a young lady named Sina, who will illustrate things I never knew or appreciated about him. As has been stated in the replies so far, Ringo wasn’t flashy, but he caught the right beat for every song, many of them unique. Many were recognizable from the first measures. Watch Sina, she will show you as she plays…

I first noticed how good Ringo was on the hit single “I Saw Her Standing There.” He drove the band like a race car with his sharp accents. He was crackling. Another of my favorites is “Taxman.” His simple riffs, punctuated by cymbal crashes between the singing, made the song irresistible. And his playing on “The End,” especially just before and during round robin of guitar breaks (Paul, George, John, three times), were indispensable.

Of course, he did! If you like any one, or all, of the approximately 300 songs the Beatles recorded, you probably feel that way, at least in part, because of the unique sound Ringo’s particular style of drumming brought to the those songs. And, of course, Ringo’s personality was a key element of their group chemistry and popularity as a group.

My take has long been this: Pete Best was fine for the band the Beatles started out to be, but not for the band they were becoming. If the Beatles were content to be a Chuck Berry/Little Richard cover band forever, there'd have been no need to replace Pete. But the Beatles had much higher ambitions. Ringo was a better drummer, but more importantly, he was a drummer capable of growing, improving and exploring new territory.

John said that Ringo wasn’t necessarily a better drummer. He was a better BEATLE. I can agree with that to a point. You can hear some of Best on old bootlegs. Then listen to Ringo. Decide who was a a better drummer. Let me also ask a rhetorical question: Who made John Lennon an expert on drummers? Ringo was a pioneer in rock drumming, and did things that others might never have thought of. He was an essential part of the Beatle sound, and a plow horse of a worker. You have to love Ringo.

He is one of the best rock and roll drummers ever. His work was and still is elegant, spare, unique, and rock solid. Before he joined The Beatles he was already a successful and sought after drummer. His additions to The Beatles music was significant and substantial. Here is what some of the best drummers in modern music had to say about the great Ringo Starr.

Pete Best was an ok drummer, but Ringo was simply better. He could adjust his playing style to fit the Beatles music and his personality was a better fit with the other boys. There are better drummers, but I think Ringo definitely earned his place among the greats.

Yes. Pete Best had timing issues and his style was not a good fit with the rhythms the Beatles were creating. Ringo’s timing was great. In addition Ringo’s personality was perfect in relation to the others so it was a complementary fit all around.

Yes Ringo added to the Beatles success in a way like no other could. It took all four talents to make them The Fab Four. He had great timing and his sense of humour or calmness helped the band in tough times.
We’ll never know. We can’t know. I don’t think the success of the Beatles is due to Ringo. I’m not sure that keeping Best in the band would have killed the Beatles. Are you?
The very tight arrangements and counter point which provided the group’s success would not have been possible with Pete Best playing drums.
